title.narrative: Integrated Health, Nutrition and WASH services through support for fixed facilities and mobile outreach through the Integrated Emergency Response Teams (IERTs)

description.narrative:
The proposed project is in line with the cluster strategic objectives by providing integrated lifesaving health, nutrition and WASH services for the cluster priority districts in Bari and Karkaar regions i.e. Iskushuban, Qandala, and Qardho districts.
The project will contribute to improving equitable access to quality life-saving curative and preventative health and nutrition services through the support of static health facilities and mobile outreach. There will be four integrated health and nutrition mobile teams in the two districts, with each district having one mobile team for Qandalla and Iskushuban while Qardho will have two mobile teams providing access in remote locations. The integrated health and nutrition mobile teams will provide outpatient consultations, routine immunizations, maternal healthcare, disease surveillance and health promotion as well as systematic identiﬁcation, referral and treatment of acutely malnourished cases by providing integrated nutrition services to out-patient therapeutic programme (OTP), Targeted Supplementary Feeding Program (TSFP) and stabilization centres. The provision of OTP services for those with Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) and the referral and treatment of SAM cases with medical complications to the nearest stabilization centre. Micronutrient supplementation, promotion of Infant and Young Child Feeding (IYCF) practices, promotion of adoption of good hygiene and sanitation practices will be done, providing treatment for all age groups, both male and female. The health and nutrition interventions will improve early identification and prevention of malnutrition, and access to primary health care, and therefore reduce excess morbidity and mortality.
Save the Children (SC) will also support seven fixed facilities, all with integrated health, nutrition, hygiene and sanitation services. Within the fixed sites that are proposed to be supported, six of these facilities already have health services provided by SC. However, SHF project will be able to integrate nutrition and hygiene and sanitation to these sites. Hygiene and sanitation support and promotion will be provided in an integrated approach in the health and nutrition sites. There will also be outreach nutrition, hygiene and health promotion within the community and in schools. This will also empower children to be agents of change for hygiene promotion.
